thread.title: Lions turn switch on Newnan with help from new starting QB
thread.title_full: Lions turn switch on Newnan with help from new starting QB

title: Lions turn switch on Newnan with help from new starting QB
text:
Lions turn switch on Newnan with help from new starting QB by 
Newnan defenders JaDarius Ingram and Tyrell Harris converge on Westlake’s Marquez Burdette. 
ATLANTA—Sometimes looking at film of your next football opponent doesn’t always help. 
Newnan learned that lesson Friday against Region 3- opponent Westlake. 
After struggling offensively at times this season, including last week in a 7-0 loss to East Coweta, the Westlake Lions flexed their athletic muscles behind a new quarterback Friday night against Newnan en route to a 41-21 Region 3- victory. 
The Lions threw a new wrinkle into their game plan, moving wide receiver Malik Willis behind center, and the Cougars couldn’t find a way to stop the athletic football player. 
Willis passed and ran for more than 200 all-purpose yards, and the Lions rallied from a 14-0 deficit to keep themselves in the race for the region title. 
“We weren’t expecting to see him at quarterback,” Newnan head coach Mike McDonald said. “He was tough and did some really big things and we couldn’t stop him.” 
Newnan (4-2, 2-1) lost for the first time in the region, but forward to next week’s homecoming game against Campbell, McDonald told his team there is still plenty to play for during the next four weeks. 
“We are still in the hunt,” he said.”We just have to stay focused.” 
Willis connected on two touchdown passes in each half during his quarterback debut. 
Willis’ 25-pass to Marquez Louder on the first play of the fourth quarter increased the lead to 27-14, but the Lions weren’t done. 
On the next series, Marquis Burdette ran 70 yards for a touchdown. 
The Lions capped their scoring when Justin Broughton scored on a 25-yard run. 
The loss spoiled a solid game by Marquis Hill, who scored two touchdowns, both from two yards out, including a final one with less than 20 seconds left. Hill finished the game with 142 yards. His totals includes runs of 52 and 62 yards. 
Quarterback Chancellor Johnson also showed he could pick up yardage on a keeper. The senior’s first two carries went for 23 and 27 yards. 
The senior quarterback also connected on some timely passes, but even after the Cougars managed to move the ball into Westlake territory, they were often unable to convert. 
“We just have to find a way to finish,” McDonald said. “We turned the ball over on downs and we missed two field goals. We can’t do that.” 
Westlake took a 20-14 lead at the end of the first half in a game that featured an explosive final three minutes of the second quarter. 
The two teams traded three touchdowns over the final 2:53 of the second quarter. 
After Hill capped a 68-yard drive with a two-yard plunge to give Newnan a 14-7 lead with just under three minutes left, the momentum quickly turned in the Lions’ favor. 
After a long kickoff set up the Lions near midfield, Willis called his own number and broke lose up the middle for a 50-yard touchdown. 
Newnan drove into the Westlake territory on its next drive but was stopped on fourth down, giving the Lions one more possession. 
Willis took advantage and hit two long passes on the drive, including a 48-yard pass to A.J. Terrell. The Lions missed on the 2-point try, but Westlake went into the half with a 20-14 lead. 
NEWNAN 7 7 0 7 — 21 
WESTLAKE 0 20 0 21 — 41 
1st Quarter 
N—Chancellor Johnson 27 run, (Rad Wyrick good) 
2nd Quarter 
W—Griffin 2 run (kick good), 6:30 
N—Marquis Hill 2--run (Wyrick good), 2:53 
W—Malik Willis 50 run (kick good), 2:40 
W—Willis 48 pass to A.J. Terrell (two-point conversion failed), .8 
4th Quarter 
W—Willis 25 pass to Marquez Louder (kick good), 11:53 
W—Marquis Burdette 70-run (kick good), 5:53 
W—Justin Broughton 25 yard (kick good), 2:20 
N—Hill 2 yard run (Wyrick kick), .20 More
